Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Equilibrium and Kinetic Studies of New Trace Element Thermobarometers
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a collaborative effort between Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI) and Syracuse University (SU) to develop tools and strategies to "reverse engineer" key minerals of Earth's continental crust - that is, to learn how and when these materials formed and the conditions experienced since their origin. Consider, for example, the benefits of being able to "read" the history of a single grain of sand simply by measuring its content of key chemical elements: Was it formed during an episode of mountain building or during a volcanic eruption? How far did it travel from its source? Was it associated with a potentially valuable ore deposit at the time of formation? This project will involve laboratory synthesis of selected minerals over a range of temperature and pressure conditions, followed by measurement of the amounts of elemental impurities incorporated during growth (the concentrations of aluminum and titanium in quartz, for example, depend strongly on the temperature and pressure of quartz formation). The broader purpose of the project is to develop "chemical tools" for all researchers to use in deciphering events and processes of our planet's past - from mountain building to formation of ore deposits.

A decade of experimental research at RPI has focused on evaluating the effects of pressure (P) and temperature (T) on the solubilities of low-abundance elements in key minerals of the continental crust. This enterprise has been called "trace-element thermobarometry" because each application is based on the concentration of a single, marginally compatible element in a common or otherwise strategic mineral phase (e.g., Ti in zircon). These thermobarometers differ in fundamental ways from "conventional" thermobarometers based on major-element phase equilibria, and they have a key advantage: if the system is properly constrained, the concentration of a single impurity in a single mineral can be used as an indicator of its crystallization T and/or P. To date, this effort has produced thermo(baro)meters based on the Ti content of zircon, the Ti content of quartz ("TitaniQ"), the Zr content of rutile, and the Zr content of titanite. The value of these thermobarometers has been enhanced significantly through experimental calibration of the diffusion laws for all relevant impurities in the phases of interest, so users can assess the robustness of the thermobarometers for specific real-world applications. Efforts to date have had significant impact in the geoscience community (as judged by literature citations), but the development of trace-element thermobarometers and the improvement of "old" ones is far from complete. The proposed work is aimed at providing a full toolbox of thermobarometers for crustal systems that includes cross-checks of the various P-T indicators. Specifically, the TitaniQ calibration will be extended to lower P for application to volcanic rocks, and Ti-in-zircon will be more thoroughly assessed for P effects. Entirely new systems and applications will also be pursued, including the development of P-T indicators based on Ti in coesite for ultra high-pressure (UHP) rocks, Al in quartz to complement TitaniQ, Si and Al in rutile, and Ti in both K-spar and in kyanite. Equilibrium studies of all new systems will be complemented by diffusion measurements of the relevant elements. Further, the pressure-volume-temperature properties of fluid inclusions in crystals from experimental run products will be used in conjunction with trace-element thermobarometers to confirm accuracy of our calibrations at relatively low P-T applications. The proposed study involves implementation of techniques specifically in experimental geochemistry, but the applications of our results extend across a substantial expanse of geoscience, including not only igneous and metamorphic petrology but also ore-deposits research, structural geology, tectonics, and sedimentology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

A goal of many geoscience studies is to determine the temperatures and pressures at which rocks crystallize—this endeavor is generally referred to as thermobarometry. Numerous common rocks have restricted mineral assemblages that do not contain the mineral(s) required for application of most existing thermobarometers. We developed new "trace-element" thermobarometers that use the pressure–temperature (P–T) dependencies of low-abundance element solubilities in common minerals. The key advantage of trace element thermobarometers is that P–T estimates are based on the concentration of a single, marginally compatible element in a common or otherwise strategic mineral phase (e.g. Al in quartz). Importantly, in most cases the elements in question are not in fact trace elements in the system of interest; however, the strategy behind the thermobarometers differs in fundamental ways from "conventional" thermobarometers (e.g. the garnet-biotite geothermometer). The key advantage of trace-element thermobarometers is that the concentration of a single impurity element in a single mineral can be used as an indicator of its crystallization conditions. 

We completed four out of the five goals described in the proposal (final project is in progress). We developed four new thermobarometers based on Al solubility in quartz, Ti solubility in quartz, Ti solubility in coesite, combined application of the Ti-in-quartz solubility model with the quartz-in-garnet elastic model, and we discovered new quartz recrystallization mechanisms (discontinuous precipitation) that can produce rutilated minerals and other enigmatic textures. Discontinuous precipitation can change mineral compositions faster than any other solid-state mechanism (e.g. diffusion). Because the new thermobarometers can be simply applied to a wide variety of common rocks, we expect that they will be widely used across the geoscience disciplines.

Research supported by the grant produced five published papers, two manuscripts are in revision, and three additional manuscripts are in preparation; the grant will ultimately produce at least ten papers. We also presented results in three invited presentations and 12 international meeting presentations.

Broader Impacts

The grant supported salaries and training of four PhDs, two MS students, a postdoc, a visiting professor, one undergraduate, and two high school students. We synthesized many thousands of crystals with specific trace elements concentrations that we distribute to the geologic community for use as reference materials for geochemical analysis.

As part of the Broader Impacts requirements, I developed outreach activities in which high school students performed real scientific mini-research projects. During summer months the program hosted high school students for four hours per day over a ten-day period to perform research in my laboratories. For this grant, the goal was for students to grow chemically zoned silicate minerals in my labs and then perform all steps required for subsequent studies of specimen chemistry and microstructure. They learned to use machining equipment to make high-pressure experimental assemblies, run experiments, prepare polished specimens, and photo-document specimens in preparation for microanalysis with our electron microprobe. We performed ~24 hours of imaging and analysis. The student’s wrote short reports on their results.

We also designed and implemented outreach programs to reach beyond Syracuse University. We participated in activities with the Liberty Partnerships Program at Syracuse University that engages NY public high schools to provide academic and career development. We presented our experimental methods and results to the Public Service Leadership Academy (PSLA) at Fowler High School in Syracuse, NY to show students how scientists work. The PSLA students and those from similar junior programs at Corcoran and Danforth Middle Schools (Syracuse, NY) participated in demonstrations in my experimental and analytical facilities. For many of the students in our outreach programs, our efforts revealed previously unforeseen career opportunities.

Microelectronic manufacturers use our results on trace element solubilities in minerals to evaluate microelectronic device design performance. They are specifically interested in Si metal components that contain Ti and/or Al metal parts. At high temperatures the metal components oxidize to form SiO2, TiO2 and Al2O3. The mutual solubilities of the three components can modify device performance and thus are of great interest to the electronics industry.

At the most basic level, the findings supported by the grant provide information on the solubility of trace elements in minerals. The P–T dependencies will be widely used as thermobarometers to estimate depth and temperature conditions of rock crystallization. While this fundamental information is intriguing in itself, ‘users’ of our results will likely tackle large scale questions such as early Earth conditions, plate-scale geochemical cycling, P–T evolution of rocks, et cetera. This information will eventually ‘trickle down’ to the greater public through outreach as described above, and through information disseminated to the public through layman-type publications and productions. In closing, I truly believe that ongoing work performed at Syracuse University has tremendous societal benefits. Every day of each week I work directly with students at all levels. The empowerment of knowledge imparted to them is tangible, gratifying and highly valuable to their societal networks.
